11243Transition Metal ChemistryTransition Met Chem0340-42851572-901XSpringer NetherlandsDordrechts11243-011-9490-2949010.1007/s11243-011-9490-2ArticleSynthesis and crystal structures of silver(I) complexes of 3(5)-methyl-5(3)-phenyl-1H-1,2,4-triazole: two isomeric infinite chains coexisting in the same crystalZhangWen-Hua1WeiXiu-Bao1JinPing-Ning1KouJun-Feng1YangGuang1egrid.207374.50000000121893846Department of ChemistryZhengzhou University450001ZhengzhouChinayang@zzu.edu.cn74201182011365459463253201127120112432011742011© Springer Science+Business Media B.V. 20112011Abstract

Reactions of 3(5)-methyl-5(3)-phenyl-1H-1,2,4-triazole (3-Me-5-Ph-tzH) with AgNO3 in the absence/presence of NH3 yield a mononuclear [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tzH)2]NO3·3H2O (1) and a polymeric [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tz)]n (2), respectively. Two structurally different infinite chains, however, with the same formula of AgC9H8N3—one is double-decked and the other single zigzag—coexist in 1:1 ratio in the crystal of 2. As far as we know, 2 is the first binary silver(I) complex based on an asymmetric triazole and represents a rare case of two supramolecular isomers coexisting in the same crystal.

Introduction

Recent years have witnessed a rapidly increasing interest in metal 1,2,4-triazolates due to their fascinating structures as well as some potential uses in materials science [1–4]. We have been concerned with the coordination chemistry of 1,2,4-triazole with Group 11 metals, with much attention being devoted to the possible structural role of the 3,5-substituents of triazole [5–12]. For a series of binary copper(I) triazolates—Cu(3,5-R2tz) (R = H, Me, Et, Pr, Bu; tz = 1,2,4-triazolate), it is found that the size/shape of the 3,5-substituents is a crucial factor to determine the dihedral angles between adjacent Cu2tz2 secondary building units (SBUs), on which the structures of the binary triazolates are derived [5, 13]. A structural study has revealed that the same factors also play an important role in dictating the structures of Ag(3,5-R2tz) (R = Me, Et, Pr, iPr, Ph); the substituents here might act as the “template” to organize the AgI-tz skeletons [8]. We have noticed that the 3,5-substituents also impart a substantial effect on the structures of Ag(I) adducts with 4-amino-3,5-dialkyl triazoles [6, 7, 10, 11, 14].

While most of the triazoles used in coordination chemistry are symmetric (3-R = 5-R) [15], only scattered reports are known concerning the metal complexes of asymmetric triazoles (3-R ≠ 5-R) [16–18]; the possible structural influence associated with the asymmetric nature of triazoles is often overlooked. As one part of our systematic investigation on the coordination chemistry of triazole, we present herewith the synthesis and structures of two Ag(I) complexes of an asymmetric triazole—3(5)-methyl-5(3)-phenyl-1H-1,2,4-triazole (3-Me-5-Ph-tzH, Scheme 1), namely mononuclear [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tzH)2]NO3·3H2O (1) and polymeric [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tz)]n (2), the latter of which is, in the family of the binary silver triazolates, the first one based on an asymmetric triazole and consists of two different kinds of 1D chains with the same formula in 1:1 ratio, therefore representing a rare case of two supramolecular isomers coexisting in the same crystal.

Results and discussion

The reaction of 3-Me-5-Ph-tzH with AgNO3 yields a mononuclear complex—[Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tzH)2]NO3·3H2O (1). Figure 1 shows the structure of the centrosymmetric complex cation of [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tzH)2]+; the Ag atom is linearly coordinated by two triazole N4 atoms (Fig. 1), with the Ag–N bond lengths being 2.134(4) and 2.128(4) Å, and the angle of N–Ag–N 179.07(19)°, respectively. Within the crystal, extensive Ntz–H···Ow and Ow–H···Ow H-bonds are found, which may contribute to the stabilization of the whole structure of 1 (w = water) (See Fig. S1 for a packing diagram of 1).

Reaction of 3-Me-5-Ph-tzH with AgNO3 in the presence of NH3 affords polymeric [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tz)]n (2), ammonia acting as a base to deprotonate the triazole and possibly also as a ligand to form diamminesilver(I) ion, which may influence conditions for the growth of single crystals.

In the asymmetric unit of 2, there are three crystallographically independent parts: part 1 consisting of six Ag atoms and six 3-Me-5-Ph-tz ligands; parts 2 and 3, each consisting of a crystallographically independent unit of Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tz), all of which propagate themselves along the b-axis, resulting in two types of infinite chains: the double-decked chain (derived from part 1, labeled as Chain A) and the single zigzag chain (derived from parts 2 or 3, labeled as Chain B).

From the structure of the Chain A, one might easily find the Ag4tz6 motif, which is formed by two parallel Ag2tz2 subunits, further joined by two additional triazolates from the pairs of Ag atoms located at the same side (Fig. 2a), and has been assigned to Ag4tz6-b in our previous paper [7] in order to distinguish it from the Ag4tz6-a motif (which can be regarded as a Ag4tz4 metallacycle with two additional triazoles situated up and down the plane of Ag4, respectively). Besides the coordinative bonds, argentophilic interactions and π–π stacking may also contribute to the formation of the Ag4tz6-b motif, as evidenced by the Ag···Ag distances (3.2013(14) and 3.2334(14) Å) and the face-to-face distances (~3.6 Å) between the correspondent pairs of aromatic rings from the upper and down Ag2tz2 subunits. Further interconnection of the Ag4tz6-b motifs by the linear two-coordinate Ag atoms from the triazole N4 positions of Ag2tz2 subunits leads to a double-decked chain (Chain A, Fig. 2b) (N–Ag–N = 177.1(3), 178.4(3)°). It is noticeable that the Ag–N distances within the Ag4tz6-b motif fall in the range of 2.182(7)–2.299(7) Å, which are slightly longer than those of Ag–N bonds interconnecting the Ag4tz6-b motifs (2.084(7) and 2.095(7) Å). Another feature that should be mentioned here is that among the six N4 positions of Ag4tz6-b, only four of them are utilized to bind to Ag atoms, resulting in two kinds of coordination modes—μ3-N1,N2,N4 and μ2-N1,N2 bridging modes for triazolates.

The single chains derived from the crystallographically independent parts 2 and 3 are structurally identical and therefore labeled as Chain B (Fig. 2c). In this type of chain, the Ag atoms are two-coordinate in a roughly linear geometry with N–Ag–N angles of 179.7(4)° and 177.1(3)°, and Ag–N distances in the range of 2.077(7)–2.087(7) Å, respectively. The triazolates adopt a μ2-N1,N4 bridging mode; this mode, together with the aforementioned two, appears simultaneously in the same crystal, indicative of the versatility of coordination patterns for triazole ligands.

The Chains A and B are arranged to array along the a-axis in the sequence of ···ABABAB··· in 1:1 ratio (Fig. 3). Intermolecular aromatic–aromatic interactions may contribute to the observed packing pattern. It is interesting that the two types of chains actually have the same formula—Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tz)—and therefore constitute a pair of supramolecular isomers [19]. While more and more examples of supramolecular isomerism have been being reported, those of two isomeric coordination polymers in the same crystal are still rare. Ciani et al. [20] made a brief (however, not exhausted) analysis of the examples of this kind in coordination chemistry, known before 2004. In our previous work, we have twice observed this phenomenon in the crystal structures of two Cd(II) complexes [21, 22]. A more recent example has been reported to have an Ag2L3 cage and its isomeric 2D sheet in the same crystal [23].

Under UV irradiation (365 nm) at room temperature, 2 gives off bright greenish yellow light. The luminescence spectrum recorded at room temperature is shown in Fig. S2; the emission maximum is located at 500–530 nm.

Conclusion

Reactions of 3-Me-5-Ph-tzH with AgNO3 in the absence/presence of NH3 afford mononuclear [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tzH)2]NO3·3H2O (1) and polymeric [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tz)]n (2), respectively; 2 is the first binary silver(I) complex based on an asymmetric triazole and represents a rare case of two supramolecular isomers coexisting in the same crystal. It should be pointed out that the structure of 2 resembles neither that of Ag(3,5-Me2-tz) nor that of Ag(3,5-Ph2-tz); the latter two triazolates exhibit 3D structures of the lig and ant topologies, respectively [8]. In view of the similar reaction conditions for these complexes, 3,5-substituents appear to be the only remaining factor to cause the observed dramatic structural diversity, although the detailed mechanism remains unraveled. The present work might also draw attention to the coordination chemistry of the asymmetric triazoles, as it is possibly very different from that of their symmetric congeners.

Experimental section

The CHN microanalyses were carried out with a Flash EA 1112 elemental analyzer. IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded on a Nicolet Impact 420 FT-IR spectrometer. Luminescence spectra were performed on an F-4500 FL spectrophotometer.

3(5)-Methyl-5(3)-phenyl-1H-1,2,4-triazole was prepared by a literature method [24]. All other reagents are commercially available and were used as received.

Preparation of [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tzH)<sub>2</sub>]NO<sub>3</sub>·3H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

An ethanol solution (2 mL) of 3-Me-5-Ph-tzH (0.2 mmol, 32 mg) was layered on the surface of an aqueous solution of AgNO3 (0.2 mmol, 34 mg) in a test tube. Colorless crystals of 1 were obtained in 60% yield within several days.

C18H24N7AgO6 (542.31) Found C 39.8, H 4.5, N 18.0; Calcd. C 39.9, H 4.5, N 18.1.

Preparation of [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tz)]<sub>n</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A solution containing AgNO3 (0.1 mmol, 17 mg) and 25% aqueous ammonia (2 mL) was mixed with a methanol solution (4 mL) of 3-Me-5-Ph-tzH (0.1 mmol, 16 mg). The resulting mixture was allowed to evaporate slowly for 1 month to yield colorless sheets of 2. Yield: 65%.

C9H8AgN3 (266.05) Found C 40.8, H 2.6, N 15.6; Calcd. C 40.6, H 3.0, N 15.8. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3,062 w, 1,631 m, 1,467 s, 1,435 s, 1,406 s, 1,336 m, 1,279 w, 1,074 w, 1,005 m, 916 w, 779 m, 742 s, 695 s, 535 w.

X-ray crystallography

Diffraction intensities were collected on a Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (0.71073 Å). Absorption corrections were applied by using the multiscan program. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by least squares techniques using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs [25]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters; hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically except for the H-atoms of water, which were located from different Fourier maps. The crystallographic data are listed in Table 1.

CCDC 809332 and 809333 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

elements.content: Reactions of 3(5)-methyl-5(3)-phenyl-1H-1,2,4-triazole (3-Me-5-Ph-tzH) with AgNO3 in the absence/presence of NH3 yield a mononuclear [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tzH)2]NO3·3H2O (1) and a polymeric [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tz)]n (2), respectively. Two structurally different infinite chains, however, with the same formula of AgC9H8N3—one is double-decked and the other single zigzag—coexist in 1:1 ratio in the crystal of 2. As far as we know, 2 is the first binary silver(I) complex based on an asymmetric triazole and represents a rare case of two supramolecular isomers coexisting in the same crystal.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Reactions of 3(5)-methyl-5(3)-phenyl-1H-1,2,4-triazole (3-Me-5-Ph-tzH) with AgNO3 in the absence/presence of NH3 yield a mononuclear [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tzH)2]NO3⋅3H2O (1) and a polymeric [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tz)]n (2), respectively. Two structurally different infinite chains, however, with the same formula of AgC9H8N3-one is double-decked and the other single zigzag-coexist in 1:1 ratio in the crystal of 2. As far as we know, 2 is the first binary silver(I) complex based on an asymmetric triazole and represents a rare case of two supramolecular isomers coexisting in the same crystal.

elements.content: Recent years have witnessed a rapidly increasing interest in metal 1,2,4-triazolates due to their fascinating structures as well as some potential uses in materials science [1–4]. We have been concerned with the coordination chemistry of 1,2,4-triazole with Group 11 metals, with much attention being devoted to the possible structural role of the 3,5-substituents of triazole [5–12]. For a series of binary copper(I) triazolates—Cu(3,5-R2tz) (R = H, Me, Et, Pr, Bu; tz = 1,2,4-triazolate), it is found that the size/shape of the 3,5-substituents is a crucial factor to determine the dihedral angles between adjacent Cu2tz2 secondary building units (SBUs), on which the structures of the binary triazolates are derived [5, 13]. A structural study has revealed that the same factors also play an important role in dictating the structures of Ag(3,5-R2tz) (R = Me, Et, Pr, iPr, Ph); the substituents here might act as the “template” to organize the AgI-tz skeletons [8]. We have noticed that the 3,5-substituents also impart a substantial effect on the structures of Ag(I) adducts with 4-amino-3,5-dialkyl triazoles [6, 7, 10, 11, 14].
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recent years have witnessed a rapidly increasing interest in metal 1,2,4-triazolates due to their fascinating structures as well as some potential uses in materials science [1-4]. We have been concerned with the coordination chemistry of 1,2,4-triazole with Group 11 metals, with much attention being devoted to the possible structural role of the 3,5-substituents of triazole [5-12]. For a series of binary copper(I) triazolates-Cu(3,5-R2tz) (R = H, Me, Et, Pr, Bu; tz = 1,2,4-triazolate), it is found that the size/shape of the 3,5-substituents is a crucial factor to determine the dihedral angles between adjacent Cu2tz2 secondary building units (SBUs), on which the structures of the binary triazolates are derived [5, 13]. A structural study has revealed that the same factors also play an important role in dictating the structures of Ag(3,5-R2tz) (R = Me, Et, Pr, iPr, Ph); the substituents here might act as the "template" to organize the AgI-tz skeletons [8]. We have noticed that the 3,5-substituents also impart a substantial effect on the structures of Ag(I) adducts with 4-amino-3,5-dialkyl triazoles [6, 7, 10, 11, 14].

elements.content: While most of the triazoles used in coordination chemistry are symmetric (3-R = 5-R) [15], only scattered reports are known concerning the metal complexes of asymmetric triazoles (3-R ≠ 5-R) [16–18]; the possible structural influence associated with the asymmetric nature of triazoles is often overlooked. As one part of our systematic investigation on the coordination chemistry of triazole, we present herewith the synthesis and structures of two Ag(I) complexes of an asymmetric triazole—3(5)-methyl-5(3)-phenyl-1H-1,2,4-triazole (3-Me-5-Ph-tzH, Scheme 1), namely mononuclear [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tzH)2]NO3·3H2O (1) and polymeric [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tz)]n (2), the latter of which is, in the family of the binary silver triazolates, the first one based on an asymmetric triazole and consists of two different kinds of 1D chains with the same formula in 1:1 ratio, therefore representing a rare case of two supramolecular isomers coexisting in the same crystal.
elements.clean_text: While most of the triazoles used in coordination chemistry are symmetric (3-R = 5-R) [15], only scattered reports are known concerning the metal complexes of asymmetric triazoles (3-R ≠ 5-R) [16-18]; the possible structural influence associated with the asymmetric nature of triazoles is often overlooked. As one part of our systematic investigation on the coordination chemistry of triazole, we present herewith the synthesis and structures of two Ag(I) complexes of an asymmetric triazole-3(5)-methyl-5(3)-phenyl-1H-1,2,4-triazole (3-Me-5-Ph-tzH, Scheme 1), namely mononuclear [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tzH)2]NO3⋅3H2O (1) and polymeric [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tz)]n (2), the latter of which is, in the family of the binary silver triazolates, the first one based on an asymmetric triazole and consists of two different kinds of 1D chains with the same formula in 1:1 ratio, therefore representing a rare case of two supramolecular isomers coexisting in the same crystal.

elements.content: The reaction of 3-Me-5-Ph-tzH with AgNO3 yields a mononuclear complex—[Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tzH)2]NO3·3H2O (1). Figure 1 shows the structure of the centrosymmetric complex cation of [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tzH)2]+; the Ag atom is linearly coordinated by two triazole N4 atoms (Fig. 1), with the Ag–N bond lengths being 2.134(4) and 2.128(4) Å, and the angle of N–Ag–N 179.07(19)°, respectively. Within the crystal, extensive Ntz–H···Ow and Ow–H···Ow H-bonds are found, which may contribute to the stabilization of the whole structure of 1 (w = water) (See Fig. S1 for a packing diagram of 1).
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

The reaction of 3-Me-5-Ph-tzH with AgNO3 yields a mononuclear complex-[Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tzH)2]NO3⋅3H2O (1). Figure 1 shows the structure of the centrosymmetric complex cation of [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tzH)2]+; the Ag atom is linearly coordinated by two triazole N4 atoms (Fig. 1), with the Ag-N bond lengths being 2.134(4) and 2.128(4) Å, and the angle of N-Ag-N 179.07(19)°, respectively. Within the crystal, extensive Ntz-H⋅⋅⋅Ow and Ow-H⋅⋅⋅Ow H-bonds are found, which may contribute to the stabilization of the whole structure of 1 (w = water) (See Fig. S1 for a packing diagram of 1).

elements.content: Reaction of 3-Me-5-Ph-tzH with AgNO3 in the presence of NH3 affords polymeric [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tz)]n (2), ammonia acting as a base to deprotonate the triazole and possibly also as a ligand to form diamminesilver(I) ion, which may influence conditions for the growth of single crystals.

elements.content: In the asymmetric unit of 2, there are three crystallographically independent parts: part 1 consisting of six Ag atoms and six 3-Me-5-Ph-tz ligands; parts 2 and 3, each consisting of a crystallographically independent unit of Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tz), all of which propagate themselves along the b-axis, resulting in two types of infinite chains: the double-decked chain (derived from part 1, labeled as Chain A) and the single zigzag chain (derived from parts 2 or 3, labeled as Chain B).
elements.clean_text: In the asymmetric unit of 2, there are three crystallographically independent parts: part 1 consisting of six Ag atoms and six 3-Me-5-Ph-tz ligands; parts 2 and 3, each consisting of a crystallographically independent unit of Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tz), all of which propagate themselves along the b-axis, resulting in two types of infinite chains: the double-decked chain (derived from part 1, labeled as Chain A) and the single zigzag chain (derived from parts 2 or 3, labeled as Chain B).

elements.content: From the structure of the Chain A, one might easily find the Ag4tz6 motif, which is formed by two parallel Ag2tz2 subunits, further joined by two additional triazolates from the pairs of Ag atoms located at the same side (Fig. 2a), and has been assigned to Ag4tz6-b in our previous paper [7] in order to distinguish it from the Ag4tz6-a motif (which can be regarded as a Ag4tz4 metallacycle with two additional triazoles situated up and down the plane of Ag4, respectively). Besides the coordinative bonds, argentophilic interactions and π–π stacking may also contribute to the formation of the Ag4tz6-b motif, as evidenced by the Ag···Ag distances (3.2013(14) and 3.2334(14) Å) and the face-to-face distances (~3.6 Å) between the correspondent pairs of aromatic rings from the upper and down Ag2tz2 subunits. Further interconnection of the Ag4tz6-b motifs by the linear two-coordinate Ag atoms from the triazole N4 positions of Ag2tz2 subunits leads to a double-decked chain (Chain A, Fig. 2b) (N–Ag–N = 177.1(3), 178.4(3)°). It is noticeable that the Ag–N distances within the Ag4tz6-b motif fall in the range of 2.182(7)–2.299(7) Å, which are slightly longer than those of Ag–N bonds interconnecting the Ag4tz6-b motifs (2.084(7) and 2.095(7) Å). Another feature that should be mentioned here is that among the six N4 positions of Ag4tz6-b, only four of them are utilized to bind to Ag atoms, resulting in two kinds of coordination modes—μ3-N1,N2,N4 and μ2-N1,N2 bridging modes for triazolates.

elements.content: The single chains derived from the crystallographically independent parts 2 and 3 are structurally identical and therefore labeled as Chain B (Fig. 2c). In this type of chain, the Ag atoms are two-coordinate in a roughly linear geometry with N–Ag–N angles of 179.7(4)° and 177.1(3)°, and Ag–N distances in the range of 2.077(7)–2.087(7) Å, respectively. The triazolates adopt a μ2-N1,N4 bridging mode; this mode, together with the aforementioned two, appears simultaneously in the same crystal, indicative of the versatility of coordination patterns for triazole ligands.

elements.content: The Chains A and B are arranged to array along the a-axis in the sequence of ···ABABAB··· in 1:1 ratio (Fig. 3). Intermolecular aromatic–aromatic interactions may contribute to the observed packing pattern. It is interesting that the two types of chains actually have the same formula—Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tz)—and therefore constitute a pair of supramolecular isomers [19]. While more and more examples of supramolecular isomerism have been being reported, those of two isomeric coordination polymers in the same crystal are still rare. Ciani et al. [20] made a brief (however, not exhausted) analysis of the examples of this kind in coordination chemistry, known before 2004. In our previous work, we have twice observed this phenomenon in the crystal structures of two Cd(II) complexes [21, 22]. A more recent example has been reported to have an Ag2L3 cage and its isomeric 2D sheet in the same crystal [23].

elements.content: Reactions of 3-Me-5-Ph-tzH with AgNO3 in the absence/presence of NH3 afford mononuclear [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tzH)2]NO3·3H2O (1) and polymeric [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tz)]n (2), respectively; 2 is the first binary silver(I) complex based on an asymmetric triazole and represents a rare case of two supramolecular isomers coexisting in the same crystal. It should be pointed out that the structure of 2 resembles neither that of Ag(3,5-Me2-tz) nor that of Ag(3,5-Ph2-tz); the latter two triazolates exhibit 3D structures of the lig and ant topologies, respectively [8]. In view of the similar reaction conditions for these complexes, 3,5-substituents appear to be the only remaining factor to cause the observed dramatic structural diversity, although the detailed mechanism remains unraveled. The present work might also draw attention to the coordination chemistry of the asymmetric triazoles, as it is possibly very different from that of their symmetric congeners.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Reactions of 3-Me-5-Ph-tzH with AgNO3 in the absence/presence of NH3 afford mononuclear [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tzH)2]NO3⋅3H2O (1) and polymeric [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tz)]n (2), respectively; 2 is the first binary silver(I) complex based on an asymmetric triazole and represents a rare case of two supramolecular isomers coexisting in the same crystal. It should be pointed out that the structure of 2 resembles neither that of Ag(3,5-Me2-tz) nor that of Ag(3,5-Ph2-tz); the latter two triazolates exhibit 3D structures of the lig and ant topologies, respectively [8]. In view of the similar reaction conditions for these complexes, 3,5-substituents appear to be the only remaining factor to cause the observed dramatic structural diversity, although the detailed mechanism remains unraveled. The present work might also draw attention to the coordination chemistry of the asymmetric triazoles, as it is possibly very different from that of their symmetric congeners.

Experimental section

The CHN microanalyses were carried out with a Flash EA 1112 elemental analyzer. IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded on a Nicolet Impact 420 FT-IR spectrometer. Luminescence spectra were performed on an F-4500 FL spectrophotometer.

elements.content:
3(5)-Methyl-5(3)-phenyl-1H-1,2,4-triazole was prepared by a literature method [24]. All other reagents are commercially available and were used as received.

Preparation of [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tzH)<sub>2</sub>]NO<sub>3</sub>·3H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

An ethanol solution (2 mL) of 3-Me-5-Ph-tzH (0.2 mmol, 32 mg) was layered on the surface of an aqueous solution of AgNO3 (0.2 mmol, 34 mg) in a test tube. Colorless crystals of 1 were obtained in 60% yield within several days.
elements.clean_text:
3(5)-Methyl-5(3)-phenyl-1H-1,2,4-triazole was prepared by a literature method [24]. All other reagents are commercially available and were used as received.

Preparation of [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tzH)2]NO3⋅3H2O (1)

An ethanol solution (2 mL) of 3-Me-5-Ph-tzH (0.2 mmol, 32 mg) was layered on the surface of an aqueous solution of AgNO3 (0.2 mmol, 34 mg) in a test tube. Colorless crystals of 1 were obtained in 60% yield within several days.

elements.content:
C18H24N7AgO6 (542.31) Found C 39.8, H 4.5, N 18.0; Calcd. C 39.9, H 4.5, N 18.1.

Preparation of [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tz)]<sub>n</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A solution containing AgNO3 (0.1 mmol, 17 mg) and 25% aqueous ammonia (2 mL) was mixed with a methanol solution (4 mL) of 3-Me-5-Ph-tzH (0.1 mmol, 16 mg). The resulting mixture was allowed to evaporate slowly for 1 month to yield colorless sheets of 2. Yield: 65%.

A solution containing AgNO3 (0.1 mmol, 17 mg) and 25% aqueous ammonia (2 mL) was mixed with a methanol solution (4 mL) of 3-Me-5-Ph-tzH (0.1 mmol, 16 mg). The resulting mixture was allowed to evaporate slowly for 1 month to yield colorless sheets of 2. Yield: 65%.

cln_elements.content:
3(5)-Methyl-5(3)-phenyl-1H-1,2,4-triazole was prepared by a literature method [24]. All other reagents are commercially available and were used as received.

Preparation of [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tzH)<sub>2</sub>]NO<sub>3</sub>·3H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

An ethanol solution (2 mL) of 3-Me-5-Ph-tzH (0.2 mmol, 32 mg) was layered on the surface of an aqueous solution of AgNO3 (0.2 mmol, 34 mg) in a test tube. Colorless crystals of 1 were obtained in 60% yield within several days.

C18H24N7AgO6 (542.31) Found C 39.8, H 4.5, N 18.0; Calcd. C 39.9, H 4.5, N 18.1.

Preparation of [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tz)]<sub>n</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A solution containing AgNO3 (0.1 mmol, 17 mg) and 25% aqueous ammonia (2 mL) was mixed with a methanol solution (4 mL) of 3-Me-5-Ph-tzH (0.1 mmol, 16 mg). The resulting mixture was allowed to evaporate slowly for 1 month to yield colorless sheets of 2. Yield: 65%.

C9H8AgN3 (266.05) Found C 40.8, H 2.6, N 15.6; Calcd. C 40.6, H 3.0, N 15.8. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3,062 w, 1,631 m, 1,467 s, 1,435 s, 1,406 s, 1,336 m, 1,279 w, 1,074 w, 1,005 m, 916 w, 779 m, 742 s, 695 s, 535 w.

An ethanol solution (2 mL) of 3-Me-5-Ph-tzH (0.2 mmol, 32 mg) was layered on the surface of an aqueous solution of AgNO3 (0.2 mmol, 34 mg) in a test tube. Colorless crystals of 1 were obtained in 60% yield within several days.

C18H24N7AgO6 (542.31) Found C 39.8, H 4.5, N 18.0; Calcd. C 39.9, H 4.5, N 18.1.

Preparation of [Ag(3-Me-5-Ph-tz)]n (2)

A solution containing AgNO3 (0.1 mmol, 17 mg) and 25% aqueous ammonia (2 mL) was mixed with a methanol solution (4 mL) of 3-Me-5-Ph-tzH (0.1 mmol, 16 mg). The resulting mixture was allowed to evaporate slowly for 1 month to yield colorless sheets of 2. Yield: 65%.

C9H8AgN3 (266.05) Found C 40.8, H 2.6, N 15.6; Calcd. C 40.6, H 3.0, N 15.8. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3,062 w, 1,631 m, 1,467 s, 1,435 s, 1,406 s, 1,336 m, 1,279 w, 1,074 w, 1,005 m, 916 w, 779 m, 742 s, 695 s, 535 w.
